95class MaskedArrayFutureWarning(FutureWarning):

98def _deprecate_argsort_axis(arr): 

99 """ 

100 Adjust the axis passed to argsort, warning if necessary 

101 

102 Parameters 

103 ---------- 

104 arr 

105 The array which argsort was called on 

106 

107 np.ma.argsort has a long-term bug where the default of the axis argument 

108 is wrong (gh-8701), which now must be kept for backwards compatibiity. 

109 Thankfully, this only makes a difference when arrays are 2- or more- 

110 dimensional, so we only need a warning then. 

111 """ 

112 if arr.ndim <= 1: 

113 # no warning needed - but switch to -1 anyway, to avoid surprising 

114 # subclasses, which are more likely to implement scalar axes. 

115 return -1 

116 else: 

117 # 2017-04-11, Numpy 1.13.0, gh-8701: warn on axis default 

118 warnings.warn( 

119 "In the future the default for argsort will be axis=-1, not the " 

120 "current None, to match its documentation and np.argsort. " 

121 "Explicitly pass -1 or None to silence this warning.", 

122 MaskedArrayFutureWarning, stacklevel=3) 

123 return None

126def doc_note(initialdoc, note): 

127 """ 

128 Adds a Notes section to an existing docstring. 

129 

130 """ 

131 if initialdoc is None: 

132 return 

133 if note is None: 

134 return initialdoc 

135 

136 notesplit = re.split(r'\n\s*?Notes\n\s*?-----', initialdoc) 

137 

138 notedoc = """\ 

139Notes 

140 ----- 

141 %s""" % note 

142 

143 if len(notesplit) > 1: 

144 notedoc = '\n\n ' + notedoc + '\n' 

145 

146 return ''.join(notesplit[:1] + [notedoc] + notesplit[1:])

149def get_object_signature(obj): 

150 """ 

151 Get the signature from obj 

152 

153 """ 

154 try: 

155 sig = formatargspec(*getargspec(obj)) 

156 except TypeError: 

157 sig = '' 

158 return sig

182############################################################################### 

183# Filling options # 

184############################################################################### 

185 

186 

187# b: boolean - c: complex - f: floats - i: integer - O: object - S: string 

188default_filler = {'b': True, 

189 'c': 1.e20 + 0.0j, 

190 'f': 1.e20, 

191 'i': 999999, 

192 'O': '?', 

193 'S': b'N/A', 

194 'u': 999999, 

195 'V': b'???', 

196 'U': u'N/A' 

197 } 

198 

199# Add datetime64 and timedelta64 types 

200for v in ["Y", "M", "W", "D", "h", "m", "s", "ms", "us", "ns", "ps", 

201 "fs", "as"]: 

202 default_filler["M8[" + v + "]"] = np.datetime64("NaT", v) 

203 default_filler["m8[" + v + "]"] = np.timedelta64("NaT", v) 

204 

205max_filler = ntypes._minvals 

206max_filler.update([(k, -np.inf) for k in [np.float32, np.float64]]) 

207min_filler = ntypes._maxvals 

208min_filler.update([(k, +np.inf) for k in [np.float32, np.float64]]) 

209if 'float128' in ntypes.typeDict: 

210 max_filler.update([(np.float128, -np.inf)]) 

211 min_filler.update([(np.float128, +np.inf)]) 

212 

213 

214def _recursive_fill_value(dtype, f): 

215 """ 

216 Recursively produce a fill value for `dtype`, calling f on scalar dtypes 

217 """ 

218 if dtype.names: 

219 vals = tuple(_recursive_fill_value(dtype[name], f) for name in dtype.names) 

220 return np.array(vals, dtype=dtype)[()] # decay to void scalar from 0d 

221 elif dtype.subdtype: 

222 subtype, shape = dtype.subdtype 

223 subval = _recursive_fill_value(subtype, f) 

224 return np.full(shape, subval) 

225 else: 

226 return f(dtype) 

227 

228 

229def _get_dtype_of(obj): 

230 """ Convert the argument for *_fill_value into a dtype """ 

231 if isinstance(obj, np.dtype): 

232 return obj 

233 elif hasattr(obj, 'dtype'): 

234 return obj.dtype 

235 else: 

236 return np.asanyarray(obj).dtype 

237 

238 

239def default_fill_value(obj): 

240 """ 

241 Return the default fill value for the argument object. 

242 

243 The default filling value depends on the datatype of the input 

244 array or the type of the input scalar: 

245 

246 ======== ======== 

247 datatype default 

248 ======== ======== 

249 bool True 

250 int 999999 

251 float 1.e20 

252 complex 1.e20+0j 

253 object '?' 

254 string 'N/A' 

255 ======== ======== 

256 

257 For structured types, a structured scalar is returned, with each field the 

258 default fill value for its type. 

259 

260 For subarray types, the fill value is an array of the same size containing 

261 the default scalar fill value. 

262 

263 Parameters 

264 ---------- 

265 obj : ndarray, dtype or scalar 

266 The array data-type or scalar for which the default fill value 

267 is returned. 

268 

269 Returns 

270 ------- 

271 fill_value : scalar 

272 The default fill value. 

273 

274 Examples 

275 -------- 

276 >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(1) 

277 999999 

278 >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(np.array([1.1, 2., np.pi])) 

279 1e+20 

280 >>> np.ma.default_fill_value(np.dtype(complex)) 

281 (1e+20+0j) 

282 

283 """ 

284 def _scalar_fill_value(dtype): 

285 if dtype.kind in 'Mm': 

286 return default_filler.get(dtype.str[1:], '?') 

287 else: 

288 return default_filler.get(dtype.kind, '?') 

289 

290 dtype = _get_dtype_of(obj) 

291 return _recursive_fill_value(dtype, _scalar_fill_value) 

292 

293 

294def _extremum_fill_value(obj, extremum, extremum_name): 

295 

296 def _scalar_fill_value(dtype): 

297 try: 

298 return extremum[dtype] 

299 except KeyError: 

300 raise TypeError( 

301 "Unsuitable type {} for calculating {}." 

302 .format(dtype, extremum_name) 

303 ) 

304 

305 dtype = _get_dtype_of(obj) 

306 return _recursive_fill_value(dtype, _scalar_fill_value) 

307 

308 

309def minimum_fill_value(obj): 

310 """ 

311 Return the maximum value that can be represented by the dtype of an object. 

312 

313 This function is useful for calculating a fill value suitable for 

314 taking the minimum of an array with a given dtype. 

315 

316 Parameters 

317 ---------- 

318 obj : ndarray, dtype or scalar 

319 An object that can be queried for it's numeric type. 

320 

321 Returns 

322 ------- 

323 val : scalar 

324 The maximum representable value. 

325 

326 Raises 

327 ------ 

328 TypeError 

329 If `obj` isn't a suitable numeric type. 

330 

331 See Also 

332 -------- 

333 maximum_fill_value : The inverse function. 

334 set_fill_value : Set the filling value of a masked array. 

335 MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value. 

336 

337 Examples 

338 -------- 

339 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

340 >>> a = np.int8() 

341 >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a) 

342 127 

343 >>> a = np.int32() 

344 >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a) 

345 2147483647 

346 

347 An array of numeric data can also be passed. 

348 

349 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.int8) 

350 >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a) 

351 127 

352 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.float32) 

353 >>> ma.minimum_fill_value(a) 

354 inf 

355 

356 """ 

357 return _extremum_fill_value(obj, min_filler, "minimum") 

358

360def maximum_fill_value(obj): 

361 """ 

362 Return the minimum value that can be represented by the dtype of an object. 

363 

364 This function is useful for calculating a fill value suitable for 

365 taking the maximum of an array with a given dtype. 

366 

367 Parameters 

368 ---------- 

369 obj : ndarray, dtype or scalar 

370 An object that can be queried for it's numeric type. 

371 

372 Returns 

373 ------- 

374 val : scalar 

375 The minimum representable value. 

376 

377 Raises 

378 ------ 

379 TypeError 

380 If `obj` isn't a suitable numeric type. 

381 

382 See Also 

383 -------- 

384 minimum_fill_value : The inverse function. 

385 set_fill_value : Set the filling value of a masked array. 

386 MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value. 

387 

388 Examples 

389 -------- 

390 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

391 >>> a = np.int8() 

392 >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a) 

393 -128 

394 >>> a = np.int32() 

395 >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a) 

396 -2147483648 

397 

398 An array of numeric data can also be passed. 

399 

400 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.int8) 

401 >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a) 

402 -128 

403 >>> a = np.array([1, 2, 3], dtype=np.float32) 

404 >>> ma.maximum_fill_value(a) 

405 -inf 

406 

407 """ 

408 return _extremum_fill_value(obj, max_filler, "maximum")

411def _recursive_set_fill_value(fillvalue, dt): 

412 """ 

413 Create a fill value for a structured dtype. 

414 

415 Parameters 

416 ---------- 

417 fillvalue: scalar or array_like 

418 Scalar or array representing the fill value. If it is of shorter 

419 length than the number of fields in dt, it will be resized. 

420 dt: dtype 

421 The structured dtype for which to create the fill value. 

422 

423 Returns 

424 ------- 

425 val: tuple 

426 A tuple of values corresponding to the structured fill value. 

427 

428 """ 

429 fillvalue = np.resize(fillvalue, len(dt.names)) 

430 output_value = [] 

431 for (fval, name) in zip(fillvalue, dt.names): 

432 cdtype = dt[name] 

433 if cdtype.subdtype: 

434 cdtype = cdtype.subdtype[0] 

435 

436 if cdtype.names: 

437 output_value.append(tuple(_recursive_set_fill_value(fval, cdtype))) 

438 else: 

439 output_value.append(np.array(fval, dtype=cdtype).item()) 

440 return tuple(output_value) 

441 

442 

443def _check_fill_value(fill_value, ndtype): 

444 """ 

445 Private function validating the given `fill_value` for the given dtype. 

446 

447 If fill_value is None, it is set to the default corresponding to the dtype. 

448 

449 If fill_value is not None, its value is forced to the given dtype. 

450 

451 The result is always a 0d array. 

452 

453 """ 

454 ndtype = np.dtype(ndtype) 

455 fields = ndtype.fields 

456 if fill_value is None: 

457 fill_value = default_fill_value(ndtype) 

458 elif fields: 

459 fdtype = [(_[0], _[1]) for _ in ndtype.descr] 

460 if isinstance(fill_value, (ndarray, np.void)): 

461 try: 

462 fill_value = np.array(fill_value, copy=False, dtype=fdtype) 

463 except ValueError: 

464 err_msg = "Unable to transform %s to dtype %s" 

465 raise ValueError(err_msg % (fill_value, fdtype)) 

466 else: 

467 fill_value = np.asarray(fill_value, dtype=object) 

468 fill_value = np.array(_recursive_set_fill_value(fill_value, ndtype), 

469 dtype=ndtype) 

470 else: 

471 if isinstance(fill_value, basestring) and (ndtype.char not in 'OSVU'): 

472 # Note this check doesn't work if fill_value is not a scalar 

473 err_msg = "Cannot set fill value of string with array of dtype %s" 

474 raise TypeError(err_msg % ndtype) 

475 else: 

476 # In case we want to convert 1e20 to int. 

477 # Also in case of converting string arrays. 

478 try: 

479 fill_value = np.array(fill_value, copy=False, dtype=ndtype) 

480 except (OverflowError, ValueError): 

481 # Raise TypeError instead of OverflowError or ValueError. 

482 # OverflowError is seldom used, and the real problem here is 

483 # that the passed fill_value is not compatible with the ndtype. 

484 err_msg = "Cannot convert fill_value %s to dtype %s" 

485 raise TypeError(err_msg % (fill_value, ndtype)) 

486 return np.array(fill_value)

489def set_fill_value(a, fill_value): 

490 """ 

491 Set the filling value of a, if a is a masked array. 

492 

493 This function changes the fill value of the masked array `a` in place. 

494 If `a` is not a masked array, the function returns silently, without 

495 doing anything. 

496 

497 Parameters 

498 ---------- 

499 a : array_like 

500 Input array. 

501 fill_value : dtype 

502 Filling value. A consistency test is performed to make sure 

503 the value is compatible with the dtype of `a`. 

504 

505 Returns 

506 ------- 

507 None 

508 Nothing returned by this function. 

509 

510 See Also 

511 -------- 

512 maximum_fill_value : Return the default fill value for a dtype. 

513 MaskedArray.fill_value : Return current fill value. 

514 MaskedArray.set_fill_value : Equivalent method. 

515 

516 Examples 

517 -------- 

518 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

519 >>> a = np.arange(5) 

520 >>> a 

521 array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

522 >>> a = ma.masked_where(a < 3, a) 

523 >>> a 

524 masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3 4], 

525 mask = [ True True True False False], 

526 fill_value=999999) 

527 >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, -999) 

528 >>> a 

529 masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3 4], 

530 mask = [ True True True False False], 

531 fill_value=-999) 

532 

533 Nothing happens if `a` is not a masked array. 

534 

535 >>> a = range(5) 

536 >>> a 

537 [0, 1, 2, 3, 4] 

538 >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, 100) 

539 >>> a 

540 [0, 1, 2, 3, 4] 

541 >>> a = np.arange(5) 

542 >>> a 

543 array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

544 >>> ma.set_fill_value(a, 100) 

545 >>> a 

546 array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

547 

548 """ 

549 if isinstance(a, MaskedArray): 

550 a.set_fill_value(fill_value) 

551 return 

552 

553 

554def get_fill_value(a): 

555 """ 

556 Return the filling value of a, if any. Otherwise, returns the 

557 default filling value for that type. 

558 

559 """ 

560 if isinstance(a, MaskedArray): 

561 result = a.fill_value 

562 else: 

563 result = default_fill_value(a) 

564 return result 

565 

566 

567def common_fill_value(a, b): 

568 """ 

569 Return the common filling value of two masked arrays, if any. 

570 

571 If ``a.fill_value == b.fill_value``, return the fill value, 

572 otherwise return None. 

573 

574 Parameters 

575 ---------- 

576 a, b : MaskedArray 

577 The masked arrays for which to compare fill values. 

578 

579 Returns 

580 ------- 

581 fill_value : scalar or None 

582 The common fill value, or None. 

583 

584 Examples 

585 -------- 

586 >>> x = np.ma.array([0, 1.], fill_value=3) 

587 >>> y = np.ma.array([0, 1.], fill_value=3) 

588 >>> np.ma.common_fill_value(x, y) 

589 3.0 

590 

591 """ 

592 t1 = get_fill_value(a) 

593 t2 = get_fill_value(b) 

594 if t1 == t2: 

595 return t1 

596 return None

599def filled(a, fill_value=None): 

600 """ 

601 Return input as an array with masked data replaced by a fill value. 

602 

603 If `a` is not a `MaskedArray`, `a` itself is returned. 

604 If `a` is a `MaskedArray` and `fill_value` is None, `fill_value` is set to 

605 ``a.fill_value``. 

606 

607 Parameters 

608 ---------- 

609 a : MaskedArray or array_like 

610 An input object. 

611 fill_value : scalar, optional 

612 Filling value. Default is None. 

613 

614 Returns 

615 ------- 

616 a : ndarray 

617 The filled array. 

618 

619 See Also 

620 -------- 

621 compressed 

622 

623 Examples 

624 -------- 

625 >>> x = np.ma.array(np.arange(9).reshape(3, 3), mask=[[1, 0, 0], 

626 ... [1, 0, 0], 

627 ... [0, 0, 0]]) 

628 >>> x.filled() 

629 array([[999999, 1, 2], 

630 [999999, 4, 5], 

631 [ 6, 7, 8]]) 

632 

633 """ 

634 if hasattr(a, 'filled'): 

635 return a.filled(fill_value) 

636 elif isinstance(a, ndarray): 

637 # Should we check for contiguity ? and a.flags['CONTIGUOUS']: 

638 return a 

639 elif isinstance(a, dict): 

640 return np.array(a, 'O') 

641 else: 

642 return np.array(a) 

643 

644 

645def get_masked_subclass(*arrays): 

646 """ 

647 Return the youngest subclass of MaskedArray from a list of (masked) arrays. 

648 

649 In case of siblings, the first listed takes over. 

650 

651 """ 

652 if len(arrays) == 1: 

653 arr = arrays[0] 

654 if isinstance(arr, MaskedArray): 

655 rcls = type(arr) 

656 else: 

657 rcls = MaskedArray 

658 else: 

659 arrcls = [type(a) for a in arrays] 

660 rcls = arrcls[0] 

661 if not issubclass(rcls, MaskedArray): 

662 rcls = MaskedArray 

663 for cls in arrcls[1:]: 

664 if issubclass(cls, rcls): 

665 rcls = cls 

666 # Don't return MaskedConstant as result: revert to MaskedArray 

667 if rcls.__name__ == 'MaskedConstant': 

668 return MaskedArray 

669 return rcls

672def getdata(a, subok=True): 

673 """ 

674 Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray. 

675 

676 Return the data of `a` (if any) as an ndarray if `a` is a ``MaskedArray``, 

677 else return `a` as a ndarray or subclass (depending on `subok`) if not. 

678 

679 Parameters 

680 ---------- 

681 a : array_like 

682 Input ``MaskedArray``, alternatively a ndarray or a subclass thereof. 

683 subok : bool 

684 Whether to force the output to be a `pure` ndarray (False) or to 

685 return a subclass of ndarray if appropriate (True, default). 

686 

687 See Also 

688 -------- 

689 getmask : Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask. 

690 getmaskarray : Return the mask of a masked array, or full array of False. 

691 

692 Examples 

693 -------- 

694 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

695 >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2) 

696 >>> a 

697 masked_array(data = 

698 [[1 --] 

699 [3 4]], 

700 mask = 

701 [[False True] 

702 [False False]], 

703 fill_value=999999) 

704 >>> ma.getdata(a) 

705 array([[1, 2], 

706 [3, 4]]) 

707 

708 Equivalently use the ``MaskedArray`` `data` attribute. 

709 

710 >>> a.data 

711 array([[1, 2], 

712 [3, 4]]) 

713 

714 """ 

715 try: 

716 data = a._data 

717 except AttributeError: 

718 data = np.array(a, copy=False, subok=subok) 

719 if not subok: 

720 return data.view(ndarray) 

721 return data 

722 

723 

724get_data = getdata 

725 

726 

727def fix_invalid(a, mask=nomask, copy=True, fill_value=None): 

728 """ 

729 Return input with invalid data masked and replaced by a fill value. 

730 

731 Invalid data means values of `nan`, `inf`, etc. 

732 

733 Parameters 

734 ---------- 

735 a : array_like 

736 Input array, a (subclass of) ndarray. 

737 mask : sequence, optional 

738 Mask. Must be convertible to an array of booleans with the same 

739 shape as `data`. True indicates a masked (i.e. invalid) data. 

740 copy : bool, optional 

741 Whether to use a copy of `a` (True) or to fix `a` in place (False). 

742 Default is True. 

743 fill_value : scalar, optional 

744 Value used for fixing invalid data. Default is None, in which case 

745 the ``a.fill_value`` is used. 

746 

747 Returns 

748 ------- 

749 b : MaskedArray 

750 The input array with invalid entries fixed. 

751 

752 Notes 

753 ----- 

754 A copy is performed by default. 

755 

756 Examples 

757 -------- 

758 >>> x = np.ma.array([1., -1, np.nan, np.inf], mask=[1] + [0]*3) 

759 >>> x 

760 masked_array(data = [-- -1.0 nan inf], 

761 mask = [ True False False False], 

762 fill_value = 1e+20) 

763 >>> np.ma.fix_invalid(x) 

764 masked_array(data = [-- -1.0 -- --], 

765 mask = [ True False True True], 

766 fill_value = 1e+20) 

767 

768 >>> fixed = np.ma.fix_invalid(x) 

769 >>> fixed.data 

770 array([ 1.00000000e+00, -1.00000000e+00, 1.00000000e+20, 

771 1.00000000e+20]) 

772 >>> x.data 

773 array([ 1., -1., NaN, Inf]) 

774 

775 """ 

776 a = masked_array(a, copy=copy, mask=mask, subok=True) 

777 invalid = np.logical_not(np.isfinite(a._data)) 

778 if not invalid.any(): 

779 return a 

780 a._mask |= invalid 

781 if fill_value is None: 

782 fill_value = a.fill_value 

783 a._data[invalid] = fill_value 

784 return a 

785

796class _DomainCheckInterval(object): 

797 """ 

798 Define a valid interval, so that : 

799 

800 ``domain_check_interval(a,b)(x) == True`` where 

801 ``x < a`` or ``x > b``. 

802 

803 """ 

804 

805 def __init__(self, a, b): 

806 "domain_check_interval(a,b)(x) = true where x < a or y > b" 

807 if (a > b): 

808 (a, b) = (b, a) 

809 self.a = a 

810 self.b = b 

811 

812 def __call__(self, x): 

813 "Execute the call behavior." 

814 # nans at masked positions cause RuntimeWarnings, even though 

815 # they are masked. To avoid this we suppress warnings. 

816 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

817 return umath.logical_or(umath.greater(x, self.b), 

818 umath.less(x, self.a)) 

819 

820 

821class _DomainTan(object): 

822 """ 

823 Define a valid interval for the `tan` function, so that: 

824 

825 ``domain_tan(eps) = True`` where ``abs(cos(x)) < eps`` 

826 

827 """ 

828 

829 def __init__(self, eps): 

830 "domain_tan(eps) = true where abs(cos(x)) < eps)" 

831 self.eps = eps 

832 

833 def __call__(self, x): 

834 "Executes the call behavior." 

835 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

836 return umath.less(umath.absolute(umath.cos(x)), self.eps)

838 

839class _DomainSafeDivide(object): 

840 """ 

841 Define a domain for safe division. 

842 

843 """ 

844 

845 def __init__(self, tolerance=None): 

846 self.tolerance = tolerance 

847 

848 def __call__(self, a, b): 

849 # Delay the selection of the tolerance to here in order to reduce numpy 

850 # import times. The calculation of these parameters is a substantial 

851 # component of numpy's import time. 

852 if self.tolerance is None: 

853 self.tolerance = np.finfo(float).tiny 

854 # don't call ma ufuncs from __array_wrap__ which would fail for scalars 

855 a, b = np.asarray(a), np.asarray(b) 

856 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

857 return umath.absolute(a) * self.tolerance >= umath.absolute(b)

860class _DomainGreater(object): 

861 """ 

862 DomainGreater(v)(x) is True where x <= v. 

863 

864 """ 

865 

866 def __init__(self, critical_value): 

867 "DomainGreater(v)(x) = true where x <= v" 

868 self.critical_value = critical_value 

869 

870 def __call__(self, x): 

871 "Executes the call behavior." 

872 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

873 return umath.less_equal(x, self.critical_value)

878 DomainGreaterEqual(v)(x) is True where x < v.

883 "DomainGreaterEqual(v)(x) = true where x < v" 

884 self.critical_value = critical_value 

885 

886 def __call__(self, x): 

887 "Executes the call behavior." 

888 with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'): 

889 return umath.less(x, self.critical_value)

892class _MaskedUFunc(object): 

893 def __init__(self, ufunc): 

894 self.f = ufunc 

895 self.__doc__ = ufunc.__doc__ 

896 self.__name__ = ufunc.__name__ 

897 

898 def __str__(self): 

899 return "Masked version of {}".format(self.f) 

900 

901 

902class _MaskedUnaryOperation(_MaskedUFunc): 

903 """ 

904 Defines masked version of unary operations, where invalid values are 

905 pre-masked. 

906 

907 Parameters 

908 ---------- 

909 mufunc : callable 

910 The function for which to define a masked version. Made available 

911 as ``_MaskedUnaryOperation.f``. 

912 fill : scalar, optional 

913 Filling value, default is 0. 

914 domain : class instance 

915 Domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*`` 

916 classes. Default is None. 

917 

918 """ 

919 

920 def __init__(self, mufunc, fill=0, domain=None): 

921 super(_MaskedUnaryOperation, self).__init__(mufunc) 

922 self.fill = fill 

923 self.domain = domain 

924 ufunc_domain[mufunc] = domain 

925 ufunc_fills[mufunc] = fill 

926 

927 def __call__(self, a, *args, **kwargs): 

928 """ 

929 Execute the call behavior. 

930 

931 """ 

932 d = getdata(a) 

933 # Deal with domain 

934 if self.domain is not None: 

935 # Case 1.1. : Domained function 

936 # nans at masked positions cause RuntimeWarnings, even though 

937 # they are masked. To avoid this we suppress warnings. 

938 with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'): 

939 result = self.f(d, *args, **kwargs) 

940 # Make a mask 

941 m = ~umath.isfinite(result) 

942 m |= self.domain(d) 

943 m |= getmask(a) 

944 else: 

945 # Case 1.2. : Function without a domain 

946 # Get the result and the mask 

947 with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'): 

948 result = self.f(d, *args, **kwargs) 

949 m = getmask(a) 

950 

951 if not result.ndim: 

952 # Case 2.1. : The result is scalarscalar 

953 if m: 

954 return masked 

955 return result 

956 

957 if m is not nomask: 

958 # Case 2.2. The result is an array 

959 # We need to fill the invalid data back w/ the input Now, 

960 # that's plain silly: in C, we would just skip the element and 

961 # keep the original, but we do have to do it that way in Python 

962 

963 # In case result has a lower dtype than the inputs (as in 

964 # equal) 

965 try: 

966 np.copyto(result, d, where=m) 

967 except TypeError: 

968 pass 

969 # Transform to 

970 masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a)) 

971 masked_result._mask = m 

972 masked_result._update_from(a) 

973 return masked_result 

974 

975 

976class _MaskedBinaryOperation(_MaskedUFunc): 

977 """ 

978 Define masked version of binary operations, where invalid 

979 values are pre-masked. 

980 

981 Parameters 

982 ---------- 

983 mbfunc : function 

984 The function for which to define a masked version. Made available 

985 as ``_MaskedBinaryOperation.f``. 

986 domain : class instance 

987 Default domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*`` 

988 classes. Default is None. 

989 fillx : scalar, optional 

990 Filling value for the first argument, default is 0. 

991 filly : scalar, optional 

992 Filling value for the second argument, default is 0. 

993 

994 """ 

995 

996 def __init__(self, mbfunc, fillx=0, filly=0): 

997 """ 

998 abfunc(fillx, filly) must be defined. 

999 

1000 abfunc(x, filly) = x for all x to enable reduce. 

1001 

1002 """ 

1003 super(_MaskedBinaryOperation, self).__init__(mbfunc) 

1004 self.fillx = fillx 

1005 self.filly = filly 

1006 ufunc_domain[mbfunc] = None 

1007 ufunc_fills[mbfunc] = (fillx, filly) 

1008 

1009 def __call__(self, a, b, *args, **kwargs): 

1010 """ 

1011 Execute the call behavior. 

1012 

1013 """ 

1014 # Get the data, as ndarray 

1015 (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b)) 

1016 # Get the result 

1017 with np.errstate(): 

1018 np.seterr(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore') 

1019 result = self.f(da, db, *args, **kwargs) 

1020 # Get the mask for the result 

1021 (ma, mb) = (getmask(a), getmask(b)) 

1022 if ma is nomask: 

1023 if mb is nomask: 

1024 m = nomask 

1025 else: 

1026 m = umath.logical_or(getmaskarray(a), mb) 

1027 elif mb is nomask: 

1028 m = umath.logical_or(ma, getmaskarray(b)) 

1029 else: 

1030 m = umath.logical_or(ma, mb) 

1031 

1032 # Case 1. : scalar 

1033 if not result.ndim: 

1034 if m: 

1035 return masked 

1036 return result 

1037 

1038 # Case 2. : array 

1039 # Revert result to da where masked 

1040 if m is not nomask and m.any(): 

1041 # any errors, just abort; impossible to guarantee masked values 

1042 try: 

1043 np.copyto(result, da, casting='unsafe', where=m) 

1044 except Exception: 

1045 pass 

1046 

1047 # Transforms to a (subclass of) MaskedArray 

1048 masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b)) 

1049 masked_result._mask = m 

1050 if isinstance(a, MaskedArray): 

1051 masked_result._update_from(a) 

1052 elif isinstance(b, MaskedArray): 

1053 masked_result._update_from(b) 

1054 return masked_result 

1055 

1056 def reduce(self, target, axis=0, dtype=None): 

1057 """ 

1058 Reduce `target` along the given `axis`. 

1059 

1060 """ 

1061 tclass = get_masked_subclass(target) 

1062 m = getmask(target) 

1063 t = filled(target, self.filly) 

1064 if t.shape == (): 

1065 t = t.reshape(1) 

1066 if m is not nomask: 

1067 m = make_mask(m, copy=1) 

1068 m.shape = (1,) 

1069 

1070 if m is nomask: 

1071 tr = self.f.reduce(t, axis) 

1072 mr = nomask 

1073 else: 

1074 tr = self.f.reduce(t, axis, dtype=dtype or t.dtype) 

1075 mr = umath.logical_and.reduce(m, axis) 

1076 

1077 if not tr.shape: 

1078 if mr: 

1079 return masked 

1080 else: 

1081 return tr 

1082 masked_tr = tr.view(tclass) 

1083 masked_tr._mask = mr 

1084 return masked_tr 

1085 

1086 def outer(self, a, b): 

1087 """ 

1088 Return the function applied to the outer product of a and b. 

1089 

1090 """ 

1091 (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b)) 

1092 d = self.f.outer(da, db) 

1093 ma = getmask(a) 

1094 mb = getmask(b) 

1095 if ma is nomask and mb is nomask: 

1096 m = nomask 

1097 else: 

1098 ma = getmaskarray(a) 

1099 mb = getmaskarray(b) 

1100 m = umath.logical_or.outer(ma, mb) 

1101 if (not m.ndim) and m: 

1102 return masked 

1103 if m is not nomask: 

1104 np.copyto(d, da, where=m) 

1105 if not d.shape: 

1106 return d 

1107 masked_d = d.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b)) 

1108 masked_d._mask = m 

1109 return masked_d 

1110 

1111 def accumulate(self, target, axis=0): 

1112 """Accumulate `target` along `axis` after filling with y fill 

1113 value. 

1114 

1115 """ 

1116 tclass = get_masked_subclass(target) 

1117 t = filled(target, self.filly) 

1118 result = self.f.accumulate(t, axis) 

1119 masked_result = result.view(tclass) 

1120 return masked_result 

1121 

1122 

1123 

1124class _DomainedBinaryOperation(_MaskedUFunc): 

1125 """ 

1126 Define binary operations that have a domain, like divide. 

1127 

1128 They have no reduce, outer or accumulate. 

1129 

1130 Parameters 

1131 ---------- 

1132 mbfunc : function 

1133 The function for which to define a masked version. Made available 

1134 as ``_DomainedBinaryOperation.f``. 

1135 domain : class instance 

1136 Default domain for the function. Should be one of the ``_Domain*`` 

1137 classes. 

1138 fillx : scalar, optional 

1139 Filling value for the first argument, default is 0. 

1140 filly : scalar, optional 

1141 Filling value for the second argument, default is 0. 

1142 

1143 """ 

1144 

1145 def __init__(self, dbfunc, domain, fillx=0, filly=0): 

1146 """abfunc(fillx, filly) must be defined. 

1147 abfunc(x, filly) = x for all x to enable reduce. 

1148 """ 

1149 super(_DomainedBinaryOperation, self).__init__(dbfunc) 

1150 self.domain = domain 

1151 self.fillx = fillx 

1152 self.filly = filly 

1153 ufunc_domain[dbfunc] = domain 

1154 ufunc_fills[dbfunc] = (fillx, filly) 

1155 

1156 def __call__(self, a, b, *args, **kwargs): 

1157 "Execute the call behavior." 

1158 # Get the data 

1159 (da, db) = (getdata(a), getdata(b)) 

1160 # Get the result 

1161 with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'): 

1162 result = self.f(da, db, *args, **kwargs) 

1163 # Get the mask as a combination of the source masks and invalid 

1164 m = ~umath.isfinite(result) 

1165 m |= getmask(a) 

1166 m |= getmask(b) 

1167 # Apply the domain 

1168 domain = ufunc_domain.get(self.f, None) 

1169 if domain is not None: 

1170 m |= domain(da, db) 

1171 # Take care of the scalar case first 

1172 if (not m.ndim): 

1173 if m: 

1174 return masked 

1175 else: 

1176 return result 

1177 # When the mask is True, put back da if possible 

1178 # any errors, just abort; impossible to guarantee masked values 

1179 try: 

1180 np.copyto(result, 0, casting='unsafe', where=m) 

1181 # avoid using "*" since this may be overlaid 

1182 masked_da = umath.multiply(m, da) 

1183 # only add back if it can be cast safely 

1184 if np.can_cast(masked_da.dtype, result.dtype, casting='safe'): 

1185 result += masked_da 

1186 except Exception: 

1187 pass 

1188 

1189 # Transforms to a (subclass of) MaskedArray 

1190 masked_result = result.view(get_masked_subclass(a, b)) 

1191 masked_result._mask = m 

1192 if isinstance(a, MaskedArray): 

1193 masked_result._update_from(a) 

1194 elif isinstance(b, MaskedArray): 

1195 masked_result._update_from(b) 

1196 return masked_result 

1197

1283def _replace_dtype_fields_recursive(dtype, primitive_dtype): 

1284 "Private function allowing recursion in _replace_dtype_fields." 

1285 _recurse = _replace_dtype_fields_recursive 

1286 

1287 # Do we have some name fields ? 

1288 if dtype.names: 

1289 descr = [] 

1290 for name in dtype.names: 

1291 field = dtype.fields[name] 

1292 if len(field) == 3: 

1293 # Prepend the title to the name 

1294 name = (field[-1], name) 

1295 descr.append((name, _recurse(field[0], primitive_dtype))) 

1296 new_dtype = np.dtype(descr) 

1297 

1298 # Is this some kind of composite a la (float,2) 

1299 elif dtype.subdtype: 

1300 descr = list(dtype.subdtype) 

1301 descr[0] = _recurse(dtype.subdtype[0], primitive_dtype) 

1302 new_dtype = np.dtype(tuple(descr)) 

1303 

1304 # this is a primitive type, so do a direct replacement 

1305 else: 

1306 new_dtype = primitive_dtype 

1307 

1308 # preserve identity of dtypes 

1309 if new_dtype == dtype: 

1310 new_dtype = dtype 

1311 

1312 return new_dtype 

1313 

1314 

1315def _replace_dtype_fields(dtype, primitive_dtype): 

1316 """ 

1317 Construct a dtype description list from a given dtype. 

1318 

1319 Returns a new dtype object, with all fields and subtypes in the given type 

1320 recursively replaced with `primitive_dtype`. 

1321 

1322 Arguments are coerced to dtypes first. 

1323 """ 

1324 dtype = np.dtype(dtype) 

1325 primitive_dtype = np.dtype(primitive_dtype) 

1326 return _replace_dtype_fields_recursive(dtype, primitive_dtype) 

1327 

1328 

1329def make_mask_descr(ndtype): 

1330 """ 

1331 Construct a dtype description list from a given dtype. 

1332 

1333 Returns a new dtype object, with the type of all fields in `ndtype` to a 

1334 boolean type. Field names are not altered. 

1335 

1336 Parameters 

1337 ---------- 

1338 ndtype : dtype 

1339 The dtype to convert. 

1340 

1341 Returns 

1342 ------- 

1343 result : dtype 

1344 A dtype that looks like `ndtype`, the type of all fields is boolean. 

1345 

1346 Examples 

1347 -------- 

1348 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1349 >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['foo', 'bar'], 

1350 'formats':[np.float32, int]}) 

1351 >>> dtype 

1352 dtype([('foo', '<f4'), ('bar', '<i4')]) 

1353 >>> ma.make_mask_descr(dtype) 

1354 dtype([('foo', '|b1'), ('bar', '|b1')]) 

1355 >>> ma.make_mask_descr(np.float32) 

1356 dtype('bool') 

1357 

1358 """ 

1359 return _replace_dtype_fields(ndtype, MaskType) 

1360 

1361 

1362def getmask(a): 

1363 """ 

1364 Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask. 

1365 

1366 Return the mask of `a` as an ndarray if `a` is a `MaskedArray` and the 

1367 mask is not `nomask`, else return `nomask`. To guarantee a full array 

1368 of booleans of the same shape as a, use `getmaskarray`. 

1369 

1370 Parameters 

1371 ---------- 

1372 a : array_like 

1373 Input `MaskedArray` for which the mask is required. 

1374 

1375 See Also 

1376 -------- 

1377 getdata : Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray. 

1378 getmaskarray : Return the mask of a masked array, or full array of False. 

1379 

1380 Examples 

1381 -------- 

1382 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1383 >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2) 

1384 >>> a 

1385 masked_array(data = 

1386 [[1 --] 

1387 [3 4]], 

1388 mask = 

1389 [[False True] 

1390 [False False]], 

1391 fill_value=999999) 

1392 >>> ma.getmask(a) 

1393 array([[False, True], 

1394 [False, False]]) 

1395 

1396 Equivalently use the `MaskedArray` `mask` attribute. 

1397 

1398 >>> a.mask 

1399 array([[False, True], 

1400 [False, False]]) 

1401 

1402 Result when mask == `nomask` 

1403 

1404 >>> b = ma.masked_array([[1,2],[3,4]]) 

1405 >>> b 

1406 masked_array(data = 

1407 [[1 2] 

1408 [3 4]], 

1409 mask = 

1410 False, 

1411 fill_value=999999) 

1412 >>> ma.nomask 

1413 False 

1414 >>> ma.getmask(b) == ma.nomask 

1415 True 

1416 >>> b.mask == ma.nomask 

1417 True 

1418 

1419 """ 

1420 return getattr(a, '_mask', nomask) 

1421 

1422 

1423get_mask = getmask 

1424 

1425 

1426def getmaskarray(arr): 

1427 """ 

1428 Return the mask of a masked array, or full boolean array of False. 

1429 

1430 Return the mask of `arr` as an ndarray if `arr` is a `MaskedArray` and 

1431 the mask is not `nomask`, else return a full boolean array of False of 

1432 the same shape as `arr`. 

1433 

1434 Parameters 

1435 ---------- 

1436 arr : array_like 

1437 Input `MaskedArray` for which the mask is required. 

1438 

1439 See Also 

1440 -------- 

1441 getmask : Return the mask of a masked array, or nomask. 

1442 getdata : Return the data of a masked array as an ndarray. 

1443 

1444 Examples 

1445 -------- 

1446 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1447 >>> a = ma.masked_equal([[1,2],[3,4]], 2) 

1448 >>> a 

1449 masked_array(data = 

1450 [[1 --] 

1451 [3 4]], 

1452 mask = 

1453 [[False True] 

1454 [False False]], 

1455 fill_value=999999) 

1456 >>> ma.getmaskarray(a) 

1457 array([[False, True], 

1458 [False, False]]) 

1459 

1460 Result when mask == ``nomask`` 

1461 

1462 >>> b = ma.masked_array([[1,2],[3,4]]) 

1463 >>> b 

1464 masked_array(data = 

1465 [[1 2] 

1466 [3 4]], 

1467 mask = 

1468 False, 

1469 fill_value=999999) 

1470 >>> >ma.getmaskarray(b) 

1471 array([[False, False], 

1472 [False, False]]) 

1473 

1474 """ 

1475 mask = getmask(arr) 

1476 if mask is nomask: 

1477 mask = make_mask_none(np.shape(arr), getattr(arr, 'dtype', None)) 

1478 return mask 

1479 

1480 

1481def is_mask(m): 

1482 """ 

1483 Return True if m is a valid, standard mask. 

1484 

1485 This function does not check the contents of the input, only that the 

1486 type is MaskType. In particular, this function returns False if the 

1487 mask has a flexible dtype. 

1488 

1489 Parameters 

1490 ---------- 

1491 m : array_like 

1492 Array to test. 

1493 

1494 Returns 

1495 ------- 

1496 result : bool 

1497 True if `m.dtype.type` is MaskType, False otherwise. 

1498 

1499 See Also 

1500 -------- 

1501 isMaskedArray : Test whether input is an instance of MaskedArray. 

1502 

1503 Examples 

1504 -------- 

1505 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1506 >>> m = ma.masked_equal([0, 1, 0, 2, 3], 0) 

1507 >>> m 

1508 masked_array(data = [-- 1 -- 2 3], 

1509 mask = [ True False True False False], 

1510 fill_value=999999) 

1511 >>> ma.is_mask(m) 

1512 False 

1513 >>> ma.is_mask(m.mask) 

1514 True 

1515 

1516 Input must be an ndarray (or have similar attributes) 

1517 for it to be considered a valid mask. 

1518 

1519 >>> m = [False, True, False] 

1520 >>> ma.is_mask(m) 

1521 False 

1522 >>> m = np.array([False, True, False]) 

1523 >>> m 

1524 array([False, True, False]) 

1525 >>> ma.is_mask(m) 

1526 True 

1527 

1528 Arrays with complex dtypes don't return True. 

1529 

1530 >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['monty', 'pithon'], 

1531 'formats':[bool, bool]}) 

1532 >>> dtype 

1533 dtype([('monty', '|b1'), ('pithon', '|b1')]) 

1534 >>> m = np.array([(True, False), (False, True), (True, False)], 

1535 dtype=dtype) 

1536 >>> m 

1537 array([(True, False), (False, True), (True, False)], 

1538 dtype=[('monty', '|b1'), ('pithon', '|b1')]) 

1539 >>> ma.is_mask(m) 

1540 False 

1541 

1542 """ 

1543 try: 

1544 return m.dtype.type is MaskType 

1545 except AttributeError: 

1546 return False 

1547 

1548 

1549def _shrink_mask(m): 

1550 """ 

1551 Shrink a mask to nomask if possible 

1552 """ 

1553 if not m.dtype.names and not m.any(): 

1554 return nomask 

1555 else: 

1556 return m 

1557 

1558 

1559def make_mask(m, copy=False, shrink=True, dtype=MaskType): 

1560 """ 

1561 Create a boolean mask from an array. 

1562 

1563 Return `m` as a boolean mask, creating a copy if necessary or requested. 

1564 The function can accept any sequence that is convertible to integers, 

1565 or ``nomask``. Does not require that contents must be 0s and 1s, values 

1566 of 0 are interepreted as False, everything else as True. 

1567 

1568 Parameters 

1569 ---------- 

1570 m : array_like 

1571 Potential mask. 

1572 copy : bool, optional 

1573 Whether to return a copy of `m` (True) or `m` itself (False). 

1574 shrink : bool, optional 

1575 Whether to shrink `m` to ``nomask`` if all its values are False. 

1576 dtype : dtype, optional 

1577 Data-type of the output mask. By default, the output mask has a 

1578 dtype of MaskType (bool). If the dtype is flexible, each field has 

1579 a boolean dtype. This is ignored when `m` is ``nomask``, in which 

1580 case ``nomask`` is always returned. 

1581 

1582 Returns 

1583 ------- 

1584 result : ndarray 

1585 A boolean mask derived from `m`. 

1586 

1587 Examples 

1588 -------- 

1589 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1590 >>> m = [True, False, True, True] 

1591 >>> ma.make_mask(m) 

1592 array([ True, False, True, True]) 

1593 >>> m = [1, 0, 1, 1] 

1594 >>> ma.make_mask(m) 

1595 array([ True, False, True, True]) 

1596 >>> m = [1, 0, 2, -3] 

1597 >>> ma.make_mask(m) 

1598 array([ True, False, True, True]) 

1599 

1600 Effect of the `shrink` parameter. 

1601 

1602 >>> m = np.zeros(4) 

1603 >>> m 

1604 array([ 0., 0., 0., 0.]) 

1605 >>> ma.make_mask(m) 

1606 False 

1607 >>> ma.make_mask(m, shrink=False) 

1608 array([False, False, False, False]) 

1609 

1610 Using a flexible `dtype`. 

1611 

1612 >>> m = [1, 0, 1, 1] 

1613 >>> n = [0, 1, 0, 0] 

1614 >>> arr = [] 

1615 >>> for man, mouse in zip(m, n): 

1616 ... arr.append((man, mouse)) 

1617 >>> arr 

1618 [(1, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 0)] 

1619 >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['man', 'mouse'], 

1620 'formats':[int, int]}) 

1621 >>> arr = np.array(arr, dtype=dtype) 

1622 >>> arr 

1623 array([(1, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 0)], 

1624 dtype=[('man', '<i4'), ('mouse', '<i4')]) 

1625 >>> ma.make_mask(arr, dtype=dtype) 

1626 array([(True, False), (False, True), (True, False), (True, False)], 

1627 dtype=[('man', '|b1'), ('mouse', '|b1')]) 

1628 

1629 """ 

1630 if m is nomask: 

1631 return nomask 

1632 

1633 # Make sure the input dtype is valid. 

1634 dtype = make_mask_descr(dtype) 

1635 

1636 # legacy boolean special case: "existence of fields implies true" 

1637 if isinstance(m, ndarray) and m.dtype.fields and dtype == np.bool_: 

1638 return np.ones(m.shape, dtype=dtype) 

1639 

1640 # Fill the mask in case there are missing data; turn it into an ndarray. 

1641 result = np.array(filled(m, True), copy=copy, dtype=dtype, subok=True) 

1642 # Bas les masques ! 

1643 if shrink: 

1644 result = _shrink_mask(result) 

1645 return result 

1646 

1647 

1648def make_mask_none(newshape, dtype=None): 

1649 """ 

1650 Return a boolean mask of the given shape, filled with False. 

1651 

1652 This function returns a boolean ndarray with all entries False, that can 

1653 be used in common mask manipulations. If a complex dtype is specified, the 

1654 type of each field is converted to a boolean type. 

1655 

1656 Parameters 

1657 ---------- 

1658 newshape : tuple 

1659 A tuple indicating the shape of the mask. 

1660 dtype : {None, dtype}, optional 

1661 If None, use a MaskType instance. Otherwise, use a new datatype with 

1662 the same fields as `dtype`, converted to boolean types. 

1663 

1664 Returns 

1665 ------- 

1666 result : ndarray 

1667 An ndarray of appropriate shape and dtype, filled with False. 

1668 

1669 See Also 

1670 -------- 

1671 make_mask : Create a boolean mask from an array. 

1672 make_mask_descr : Construct a dtype description list from a given dtype. 

1673 

1674 Examples 

1675 -------- 

1676 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1677 >>> ma.make_mask_none((3,)) 

1678 array([False, False, False]) 

1679 

1680 Defining a more complex dtype. 

1681 

1682 >>> dtype = np.dtype({'names':['foo', 'bar'], 

1683 'formats':[np.float32, int]}) 

1684 >>> dtype 

1685 dtype([('foo', '<f4'), ('bar', '<i4')]) 

1686 >>> ma.make_mask_none((3,), dtype=dtype) 

1687 array([(False, False), (False, False), (False, False)], 

1688 dtype=[('foo', '|b1'), ('bar', '|b1')]) 

1689 

1690 """ 

1691 if dtype is None: 

1692 result = np.zeros(newshape, dtype=MaskType) 

1693 else: 

1694 result = np.zeros(newshape, dtype=make_mask_descr(dtype)) 

1695 return result 

1696 

1697 

1698def mask_or(m1, m2, copy=False, shrink=True): 

1699 """ 

1700 Combine two masks with the ``logical_or`` operator. 

1701 

1702 The result may be a view on `m1` or `m2` if the other is `nomask` 

1703 (i.e. False). 

1704 

1705 Parameters 

1706 ---------- 

1707 m1, m2 : array_like 

1708 Input masks. 

1709 copy : bool, optional 

1710 If copy is False and one of the inputs is `nomask`, return a view 

1711 of the other input mask. Defaults to False. 

1712 shrink : bool, optional 

1713 Whether to shrink the output to `nomask` if all its values are 

1714 False. Defaults to True. 

1715 

1716 Returns 

1717 ------- 

1718 mask : output mask 

1719 The result masks values that are masked in either `m1` or `m2`. 

1720 

1721 Raises 

1722 ------ 

1723 ValueError 

1724 If `m1` and `m2` have different flexible dtypes. 

1725 

1726 Examples 

1727 -------- 

1728 >>> m1 = np.ma.make_mask([0, 1, 1, 0]) 

1729 >>> m2 = np.ma.make_mask([1, 0, 0, 0]) 

1730 >>> np.ma.mask_or(m1, m2) 

1731 array([ True, True, True, False]) 

1732 

1733 """ 

1734 

1735 def _recursive_mask_or(m1, m2, newmask): 

1736 names = m1.dtype.names 

1737 for name in names: 

1738 current1 = m1[name] 

1739 if current1.dtype.names: 

1740 _recursive_mask_or(current1, m2[name], newmask[name]) 

1741 else: 

1742 umath.logical_or(current1, m2[name], newmask[name]) 

1743 return 

1744 

1745 if (m1 is nomask) or (m1 is False): 

1746 dtype = getattr(m2, 'dtype', MaskType) 

1747 return make_mask(m2, copy=copy, shrink=shrink, dtype=dtype) 

1748 if (m2 is nomask) or (m2 is False): 

1749 dtype = getattr(m1, 'dtype', MaskType) 

1750 return make_mask(m1, copy=copy, shrink=shrink, dtype=dtype) 

1751 if m1 is m2 and is_mask(m1): 

1752 return m1 

1753 (dtype1, dtype2) = (getattr(m1, 'dtype', None), getattr(m2, 'dtype', None)) 

1754 if (dtype1 != dtype2): 

1755 raise ValueError("Incompatible dtypes '%s'<>'%s'" % (dtype1, dtype2)) 

1756 if dtype1.names: 

1757 # Allocate an output mask array with the properly broadcast shape. 

1758 newmask = np.empty(np.broadcast(m1, m2).shape, dtype1) 

1759 _recursive_mask_or(m1, m2, newmask) 

1760 return newmask 

1761 return make_mask(umath.logical_or(m1, m2), copy=copy, shrink=shrink) 

1762 

1763 

1764def flatten_mask(mask): 

1765 """ 

1766 Returns a completely flattened version of the mask, where nested fields 

1767 are collapsed. 

1768 

1769 Parameters 

1770 ---------- 

1771 mask : array_like 

1772 Input array, which will be interpreted as booleans. 

1773 

1774 Returns 

1775 ------- 

1776 flattened_mask : ndarray of bools 

1777 The flattened input. 

1778 

1779 Examples 

1780 -------- 

1781 >>> mask = np.array([0, 0, 1]) 

1782 >>> flatten_mask(mask) 

1783 array([False, False, True]) 

1784 

1785 >>> mask = np.array([(0, 0), (0, 1)], dtype=[('a', bool), ('b', bool)]) 

1786 >>> flatten_mask(mask) 

1787 array([False, False, False, True]) 

1788 

1789 >>> mdtype = [('a', bool), ('b', [('ba', bool), ('bb', bool)])] 

1790 >>> mask = np.array([(0, (0, 0)), (0, (0, 1))], dtype=mdtype) 

1791 >>> flatten_mask(mask) 

1792 array([False, False, False, False, False, True]) 

1793 

1794 """ 

1795 

1796 def _flatmask(mask): 

1797 "Flatten the mask and returns a (maybe nested) sequence of booleans." 

1798 mnames = mask.dtype.names 

1799 if mnames: 

1800 return [flatten_mask(mask[name]) for name in mnames] 

1801 else: 

1802 return mask 

1803 

1804 def _flatsequence(sequence): 

1805 "Generates a flattened version of the sequence." 

1806 try: 

1807 for element in sequence: 

1808 if hasattr(element, '__iter__'): 

1809 for f in _flatsequence(element): 

1810 yield f 

1811 else: 

1812 yield element 

1813 except TypeError: 

1814 yield sequence 

1815 

1816 mask = np.asarray(mask) 

1817 flattened = _flatsequence(_flatmask(mask)) 

1818 return np.array([_ for _ in flattened], dtype=bool) 

1819 

1820 

1821def _check_mask_axis(mask, axis, keepdims=np._NoValue): 

1822 "Check whether there are masked values along the given axis" 

1823 kwargs = {} if keepdims is np._NoValue else {'keepdims': keepdims} 

1824 if mask is not nomask: 

1825 return mask.all(axis=axis, **kwargs) 

1826 return nomask 

1827 

1828 

1829############################################################################### 

1830# Masking functions # 

1831############################################################################### 

1832 

1833def masked_where(condition, a, copy=True): 

1834 """ 

1835 Mask an array where a condition is met. 

1836 

1837 Return `a` as an array masked where `condition` is True. 

1838 Any masked values of `a` or `condition` are also masked in the output. 

1839 

1840 Parameters 

1841 ---------- 

1842 condition : array_like 

1843 Masking condition. When `condition` tests floating point values for 

1844 equality, consider using ``masked_values`` instead. 

1845 a : array_like 

1846 Array to mask. 

1847 copy : bool 

1848 If True (default) make a copy of `a` in the result. If False modify 

1849 `a` in place and return a view. 

1850 

1851 Returns 

1852 ------- 

1853 result : MaskedArray 

1854 The result of masking `a` where `condition` is True. 

1855 

1856 See Also 

1857 -------- 

1858 masked_values : Mask using floating point equality. 

1859 masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value. 

1860 masked_not_equal : Mask where `not` equal to a given value. 

1861 masked_less_equal : Mask where less than or equal to a given value. 

1862 masked_greater_equal : Mask where greater than or equal to a given value. 

1863 masked_less : Mask where less than a given value. 

1864 masked_greater : Mask where greater than a given value. 

1865 masked_inside : Mask inside a given interval. 

1866 masked_outside : Mask outside a given interval. 

1867 masked_invalid : Mask invalid values (NaNs or infs). 

1868 

1869 Examples 

1870 -------- 

1871 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1872 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

1873 >>> a 

1874 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

1875 >>> ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a) 

1876 masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3], 

1877 mask = [ True True True False], 

1878 fill_value=999999) 

1879 

1880 Mask array `b` conditional on `a`. 

1881 

1882 >>> b = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'] 

1883 >>> ma.masked_where(a == 2, b) 

1884 masked_array(data = [a b -- d], 

1885 mask = [False False True False], 

1886 fill_value=N/A) 

1887 

1888 Effect of the `copy` argument. 

1889 

1890 >>> c = ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a) 

1891 >>> c 

1892 masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3], 

1893 mask = [ True True True False], 

1894 fill_value=999999) 

1895 >>> c[0] = 99 

1896 >>> c 

1897 masked_array(data = [99 -- -- 3], 

1898 mask = [False True True False], 

1899 fill_value=999999) 

1900 >>> a 

1901 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

1902 >>> c = ma.masked_where(a <= 2, a, copy=False) 

1903 >>> c[0] = 99 

1904 >>> c 

1905 masked_array(data = [99 -- -- 3], 

1906 mask = [False True True False], 

1907 fill_value=999999) 

1908 >>> a 

1909 array([99, 1, 2, 3]) 

1910 

1911 When `condition` or `a` contain masked values. 

1912 

1913 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

1914 >>> a = ma.masked_where(a == 2, a) 

1915 >>> a 

1916 masked_array(data = [0 1 -- 3], 

1917 mask = [False False True False], 

1918 fill_value=999999) 

1919 >>> b = np.arange(4) 

1920 >>> b = ma.masked_where(b == 0, b) 

1921 >>> b 

1922 masked_array(data = [-- 1 2 3], 

1923 mask = [ True False False False], 

1924 fill_value=999999) 

1925 >>> ma.masked_where(a == 3, b) 

1926 masked_array(data = [-- 1 -- --], 

1927 mask = [ True False True True], 

1928 fill_value=999999) 

1929 

1930 """ 

1931 # Make sure that condition is a valid standard-type mask. 

1932 cond = make_mask(condition, shrink=False) 

1933 a = np.array(a, copy=copy, subok=True) 

1934 

1935 (cshape, ashape) = (cond.shape, a.shape) 

1936 if cshape and cshape != ashape: 

1937 raise IndexError("Inconsistent shape between the condition and the input" 

1938 " (got %s and %s)" % (cshape, ashape)) 

1939 if hasattr(a, '_mask'): 

1940 cond = mask_or(cond, a._mask) 

1941 cls = type(a) 

1942 else: 

1943 cls = MaskedArray 

1944 result = a.view(cls) 

1945 # Assign to *.mask so that structured masks are handled correctly. 

1946 result.mask = _shrink_mask(cond) 

1947 return result 

1948 

1949 

1950def masked_greater(x, value, copy=True): 

1951 """ 

1952 Mask an array where greater than a given value. 

1953 

1954 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

1955 `condition` = (x > value). 

1956 

1957 See Also 

1958 -------- 

1959 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

1960 

1961 Examples 

1962 -------- 

1963 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1964 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

1965 >>> a 

1966 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

1967 >>> ma.masked_greater(a, 2) 

1968 masked_array(data = [0 1 2 --], 

1969 mask = [False False False True], 

1970 fill_value=999999) 

1971 

1972 """ 

1973 return masked_where(greater(x, value), x, copy=copy) 

1974 

1975 

1976def masked_greater_equal(x, value, copy=True): 

1977 """ 

1978 Mask an array where greater than or equal to a given value. 

1979 

1980 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

1981 `condition` = (x >= value). 

1982 

1983 See Also 

1984 -------- 

1985 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

1986 

1987 Examples 

1988 -------- 

1989 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

1990 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

1991 >>> a 

1992 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

1993 >>> ma.masked_greater_equal(a, 2) 

1994 masked_array(data = [0 1 -- --], 

1995 mask = [False False True True], 

1996 fill_value=999999) 

1997 

1998 """ 

1999 return masked_where(greater_equal(x, value), x, copy=copy)

2002def masked_less(x, value, copy=True): 

2003 """ 

2004 Mask an array where less than a given value. 

2005 

2006 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

2007 `condition` = (x < value). 

2008 

2009 See Also 

2010 -------- 

2011 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2012 

2013 Examples 

2014 -------- 

2015 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2016 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

2017 >>> a 

2018 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

2019 >>> ma.masked_less(a, 2) 

2020 masked_array(data = [-- -- 2 3], 

2021 mask = [ True True False False], 

2022 fill_value=999999) 

2023 

2024 """ 

2025 return masked_where(less(x, value), x, copy=copy) 

2026 

2027 

2028def masked_less_equal(x, value, copy=True): 

2029 """ 

2030 Mask an array where less than or equal to a given value. 

2031 

2032 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

2033 `condition` = (x <= value). 

2034 

2035 See Also 

2036 -------- 

2037 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2038 

2039 Examples 

2040 -------- 

2041 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2042 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

2043 >>> a 

2044 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

2045 >>> ma.masked_less_equal(a, 2) 

2046 masked_array(data = [-- -- -- 3], 

2047 mask = [ True True True False], 

2048 fill_value=999999) 

2049 

2050 """ 

2051 return masked_where(less_equal(x, value), x, copy=copy)

2054def masked_not_equal(x, value, copy=True): 

2055 """ 

2056 Mask an array where `not` equal to a given value. 

2057 

2058 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

2059 `condition` = (x != value). 

2060

2063 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met.

2072 masked_array(data = [-- -- 2 --], 

2073 mask = [ True True False True], 

2074 fill_value=999999) 

2075 

2076 """ 

2077 return masked_where(not_equal(x, value), x, copy=copy)

2080def masked_equal(x, value, copy=True): 

2081 """ 

2082 Mask an array where equal to a given value. 

2083 

2084 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

2085 `condition` = (x == value). For floating point arrays, 

2086 consider using ``masked_values(x, value)``. 

2087 

2088 See Also 

2089 -------- 

2090 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2091 masked_values : Mask using floating point equality. 

2092 

2093 Examples 

2094 -------- 

2095 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2096 >>> a = np.arange(4) 

2097 >>> a 

2098 array([0, 1, 2, 3]) 

2099 >>> ma.masked_equal(a, 2) 

2100 masked_array(data = [0 1 -- 3], 

2101 mask = [False False True False], 

2102 fill_value=999999) 

2103 

2104 """ 

2105 output = masked_where(equal(x, value), x, copy=copy) 

2106 output.fill_value = value 

2107 return output

2110def masked_inside(x, v1, v2, copy=True): 

2111 """ 

2112 Mask an array inside a given interval. 

2113 

2114 Shortcut to ``masked_where``, where `condition` is True for `x` inside 

2115 the interval [v1,v2] (v1 <= x <= v2). The boundaries `v1` and `v2` 

2116 can be given in either order. 

2117 

2118 See Also 

2119 -------- 

2120 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2121 

2122 Notes 

2123 ----- 

2124 The array `x` is prefilled with its filling value. 

2125 

2126 Examples 

2127 -------- 

2128 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2129 >>> x = [0.31, 1.2, 0.01, 0.2, -0.4, -1.1] 

2130 >>> ma.masked_inside(x, -0.3, 0.3) 

2131 masked_array(data = [0.31 1.2 -- -- -0.4 -1.1], 

2132 mask = [False False True True False False], 

2133 fill_value=1e+20) 

2134 

2135 The order of `v1` and `v2` doesn't matter. 

2136 

2137 >>> ma.masked_inside(x, 0.3, -0.3) 

2138 masked_array(data = [0.31 1.2 -- -- -0.4 -1.1], 

2139 mask = [False False True True False False], 

2140 fill_value=1e+20) 

2141 

2142 """ 

2143 if v2 < v1: 

2144 (v1, v2) = (v2, v1) 

2145 xf = filled(x) 

2146 condition = (xf >= v1) & (xf <= v2) 

2147 return masked_where(condition, x, copy=copy) 

2148 

2149 

2150def masked_outside(x, v1, v2, copy=True): 

2151 """ 

2152 Mask an array outside a given interval. 

2153 

2154 Shortcut to ``masked_where``, where `condition` is True for `x` outside 

2155 the interval [v1,v2] (x < v1)|(x > v2). 

2156 The boundaries `v1` and `v2` can be given in either order. 

2157 

2158 See Also 

2159 -------- 

2160 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2161 

2162 Notes 

2163 ----- 

2164 The array `x` is prefilled with its filling value. 

2165 

2166 Examples 

2167 -------- 

2168 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2169 >>> x = [0.31, 1.2, 0.01, 0.2, -0.4, -1.1] 

2170 >>> ma.masked_outside(x, -0.3, 0.3) 

2171 masked_array(data = [-- -- 0.01 0.2 -- --], 

2172 mask = [ True True False False True True], 

2173 fill_value=1e+20) 

2174 

2175 The order of `v1` and `v2` doesn't matter. 

2176 

2177 >>> ma.masked_outside(x, 0.3, -0.3) 

2178 masked_array(data = [-- -- 0.01 0.2 -- --], 

2179 mask = [ True True False False True True], 

2180 fill_value=1e+20) 

2181 

2182 """ 

2183 if v2 < v1: 

2184 (v1, v2) = (v2, v1) 

2185 xf = filled(x) 

2186 condition = (xf < v1) | (xf > v2) 

2187 return masked_where(condition, x, copy=copy)

2190def masked_object(x, value, copy=True, shrink=True): 

2191 """ 

2192 Mask the array `x` where the data are exactly equal to value. 

2193 

2194 This function is similar to `masked_values`, but only suitable 

2195 for object arrays: for floating point, use `masked_values` instead. 

2196 

2197 Parameters 

2198 ---------- 

2199 x : array_like 

2200 Array to mask 

2201 value : object 

2202 Comparison value 

2203 copy : {True, False}, optional 

2204 Whether to return a copy of `x`. 

2205 shrink : {True, False}, optional 

2206 Whether to collapse a mask full of False to nomask 

2207 

2208 Returns 

2209 ------- 

2210 result : MaskedArray 

2211 The result of masking `x` where equal to `value`. 

2212 

2213 See Also 

2214 -------- 

2215 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2216 masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value (integers). 

2217 masked_values : Mask using floating point equality. 

2218 

2219 Examples 

2220 -------- 

2221 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2222 >>> food = np.array(['green_eggs', 'ham'], dtype=object) 

2223 >>> # don't eat spoiled food 

2224 >>> eat = ma.masked_object(food, 'green_eggs') 

2225 >>> print(eat) 

2226 [-- ham] 

2227 >>> # plain ol` ham is boring 

2228 >>> fresh_food = np.array(['cheese', 'ham', 'pineapple'], dtype=object) 

2229 >>> eat = ma.masked_object(fresh_food, 'green_eggs') 

2230 >>> print(eat) 

2231 [cheese ham pineapple] 

2232 

2233 Note that `mask` is set to ``nomask`` if possible. 

2234 

2235 >>> eat 

2236 masked_array(data = [cheese ham pineapple], 

2237 mask = False, 

2238 fill_value=?) 

2239 

2240 """ 

2241 if isMaskedArray(x): 

2242 condition = umath.equal(x._data, value) 

2243 mask = x._mask 

2244 else: 

2245 condition = umath.equal(np.asarray(x), value) 

2246 mask = nomask 

2247 mask = mask_or(mask, make_mask(condition, shrink=shrink)) 

2248 return masked_array(x, mask=mask, copy=copy, fill_value=value) 

2249 

2250 

2251def masked_values(x, value, rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-8, copy=True, shrink=True): 

2252 """ 

2253 Mask using floating point equality. 

2254 

2255 Return a MaskedArray, masked where the data in array `x` are approximately 

2256 equal to `value`, determined using `isclose`. The default tolerances for 

2257 `masked_values` are the same as those for `isclose`. 

2258 

2259 For integer types, exact equality is used, in the same way as 

2260 `masked_equal`. 

2261 

2262 The fill_value is set to `value` and the mask is set to ``nomask`` if 

2263 possible. 

2264 

2265 Parameters 

2266 ---------- 

2267 x : array_like 

2268 Array to mask. 

2269 value : float 

2270 Masking value. 

2271 rtol, atol : float, optional 

2272 Tolerance parameters passed on to `isclose` 

2273 copy : bool, optional 

2274 Whether to return a copy of `x`. 

2275 shrink : bool, optional 

2276 Whether to collapse a mask full of False to ``nomask``. 

2277 

2278 Returns 

2279 ------- 

2280 result : MaskedArray 

2281 The result of masking `x` where approximately equal to `value`. 

2282 

2283 See Also 

2284 -------- 

2285 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2286 masked_equal : Mask where equal to a given value (integers). 

2287 

2288 Examples 

2289 -------- 

2290 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2291 >>> x = np.array([1, 1.1, 2, 1.1, 3]) 

2292 >>> ma.masked_values(x, 1.1) 

2293 masked_array(data = [1.0 -- 2.0 -- 3.0], 

2294 mask = [False True False True False], 

2295 fill_value=1.1) 

2296 

2297 Note that `mask` is set to ``nomask`` if possible. 

2298 

2299 >>> ma.masked_values(x, 1.5) 

2300 masked_array(data = [ 1. 1.1 2. 1.1 3. ], 

2301 mask = False, 

2302 fill_value=1.5) 

2303 

2304 For integers, the fill value will be different in general to the 

2305 result of ``masked_equal``. 

2306 

2307 >>> x = np.arange(5) 

2308 >>> x 

2309 array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

2310 >>> ma.masked_values(x, 2) 

2311 masked_array(data = [0 1 -- 3 4], 

2312 mask = [False False True False False], 

2313 fill_value=2) 

2314 >>> ma.masked_equal(x, 2) 

2315 masked_array(data = [0 1 -- 3 4], 

2316 mask = [False False True False False], 

2317 fill_value=999999) 

2318 

2319 """ 

2320 xnew = filled(x, value) 

2321 if np.issubdtype(xnew.dtype, np.floating): 

2322 mask = np.isclose(xnew, value, atol=atol, rtol=rtol) 

2323 else: 

2324 mask = umath.equal(xnew, value) 

2325 ret = masked_array(xnew, mask=mask, copy=copy, fill_value=value) 

2326 if shrink: 

2327 ret.shrink_mask() 

2328 return ret 

2329 

2330 

2331def masked_invalid(a, copy=True): 

2332 """ 

2333 Mask an array where invalid values occur (NaNs or infs). 

2334 

2335 This function is a shortcut to ``masked_where``, with 

2336 `condition` = ~(np.isfinite(a)). Any pre-existing mask is conserved. 

2337 Only applies to arrays with a dtype where NaNs or infs make sense 

2338 (i.e. floating point types), but accepts any array_like object. 

2339 

2340 See Also 

2341 -------- 

2342 masked_where : Mask where a condition is met. 

2343 

2344 Examples 

2345 -------- 

2346 >>> import numpy.ma as ma 

2347 >>> a = np.arange(5, dtype=float) 

2348 >>> a[2] = np.NaN 

2349 >>> a[3] = np.PINF 

2350 >>> a 

2351 array([ 0., 1., NaN, Inf, 4.]) 

2352 >>> ma.masked_invalid(a) 

2353 masked_array(data = [0.0 1.0 -- -- 4.0], 

2354 mask = [False False True True False], 

2355 fill_value=1e+20) 

2356 

2357 """ 

2358 a = np.array(a, copy=copy, subok=True) 

2359 mask = getattr(a, '_mask', None) 

2360 if mask is not None: 

2361 condition = ~(np.isfinite(getdata(a))) 

2362 if mask is not nomask: 

2363 condition |= mask 

2364 cls = type(a) 

2365 else: 

2366 condition = ~(np.isfinite(a)) 

2367 cls = MaskedArray 

2368 result = a.view(cls) 

2369 result._mask = condition 

2370 return result

2429def _recursive_printoption(result, mask, printopt): 

2430 """ 

2431 Puts printoptions in result where mask is True. 

2432 

2433 Private function allowing for recursion 

2434 

2435 """ 

2436 names = result.dtype.names 

2437 if names: 

2438 for name in names: 

2439 curdata = result[name] 

2440 curmask = mask[name] 

2441 _recursive_printoption(curdata, curmask, printopt) 

2442 else: 

2443 np.copyto(result, printopt, where=mask) 

2444 return

2480 

2481def _recursive_filled(a, mask, fill_value): 

2482 """ 

2483 Recursively fill `a` with `fill_value`. 

2484 

2485 """ 

2486 names = a.dtype.names 

2487 for name in names: 

2488 current = a[name] 

2489 if current.dtype.names: 

2490 _recursive_filled(current, mask[name], fill_value[name]) 

2491 else: 

2492 np.copyto(current, fill_value[name], where=mask[name])
